body_html:
Selective registration draws from a larger set of potential ops than the regular TF build. It appears what you have done with your macro definitions is to set it to include all these ops, excluding only the gradients which are used for training. Gradients are already excluded by default, and you've added more ops, therefore it makes sense you'll get a larger resulting library.

As explained in #11936, you'll want to used print_selective_registration_header.py to generate a custom header which only causes the ops you actually use to be linked in.
body_text:
Selective registration draws from a larger set of potential ops than the regular TF build. It appears what you have done with your macro definitions is to set it to include all these ops, excluding only the gradients which are used for training. Gradients are already excluded by default, and you've added more ops, therefore it makes sense you'll get a larger resulting library.
As explained in #11936, you'll want to used print_selective_registration_header.py to generate a custom header which only causes the ops you actually use to be linked in.
body:
Selective registration draws from a larger set of potential ops than the regular TF build. It appears what you have done with your macro definitions is to set it to include all these ops, excluding only the gradients which are used for training. Gradients are already excluded by default, and you've added more ops, therefore it makes sense you'll get a larger resulting library.

As explained in #11936, you'll want to used [print_selective_registration_header.py](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/tools/print_selective_registration_header.py) to generate a custom header which only causes the ops you actually use to be linked in.
